#Text=Lampenflora is a complex community of organisms growing on illuminated areas such as rocky surfaces, sediment and artificial materials around lamps.
#Text=The Kras is a limestone plateau situated above the Trieste Bay in the northern Adriatic Sea.

#Text=The word epikarst came into widespread use in the 1990s following the definition by Mangin (1973) of an epikarst aquifer as a perched saturated zone within the superficial part of the karst that stores a part of the infiltrated water (Bakalowicz, 2012).
#Text=Dry valleys are often defined as thosewithout, or with only a temporary, watercourse (Sweeting, 1973).
#Text=Time series analysis are signal processing methods belonging to this category, and are mostly used to improve the understanding of the hydrological behaviour of karst systems.
#Text=Speleogenesis (karstic) is a mass-transfer process, which critically depends on both, the aggressiveness of groundwater and its circulation (movement).
#Text=Aggressiveness is an attribute of groundwater that corresponds to a chemical potential for mobilization of a dissolved matter from the rock.
#Text=Tafoni geomorphology designates a hollow shape rounded several decimeters to several meters, carved by erosion in the coastal carbonates.
#Text=Sea caves, also known as littoral caves, are a type of cave formed primarily by wave action.
#Text=In desert environments, spring mounds are hot beds of biological activity that, like soils, tend to be zones of high PCO2.
#Text=The term epigenesis is widely used in Earth Sciences, employing epi - in the second, temporal sense, along with a complementary syngenesis.
#Text=Hypogene karstification is defined as upward movement �of the cave-forming agent� (sensu Klimchouk, 2007, 2012).

#Text=The term doline, of Slavonic origin, means literally valley but actually it has been used since a long time to indicate more or less well defined topographically depressed areas related to karst.
#Text=Caves are natural underground laboratories where crystal growth processes can be directly observed.

#Text=Influxes of sediment into a cave system fundamentally alters the way cave passages develop, either by alluviation in a vadose environment, or upwards dissolution in a phreatic environment through a process commonly known as paragenesis.
